meanings.definition: Persuade by flattery or gentle urging.
meanings.sent1: She tried to coax her cat out from under the bed with a treat.
meanings.sent2: The teacher used kind words to coax the shy student to participate in class.
meanings.sent3: The puppy's attempt to coax the grumpy old dog to play ended in a hilarious chase around the yard.
meanings.sent4: The magician was able to coax a rabbit out of his hat with a flick of his wand.
meanings.sent5: The sweet melody of the flute seemed to coax the birds out of hiding, filling the forest with their songs.

meanings.definition: To manipulate with great skill or success.
meanings.sent1: The skilled chef was able to coax the flavors of the dish to perfection.
meanings.sent2: The artist knew how to coax the paint on the canvas to create a beautiful masterpiece.
meanings.sent3: The clever raccoon managed to coax the lid off the trash can, much to the surprise of the homeowners.
meanings.sent4: The experienced negotiator could coax even the toughest clients into making a deal.
meanings.sent5: The mechanic was able to coax the old engine back to life with a few expert adjustments.
